text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen I'm so 
excited for today's recipe because we are doing

hotpot now there's a few different types of hot 
pots in Thailand and the one I want to share with

you today is one from the northeast of Thailand 
called jim jum now jim means to dip and jum

means to dunk and that's basically what you'll be 
doing you're dunking things in the pot and then

dipping it in your dipping sauce now I love hot 
pot for parties because it's very interactive it's

a lot of fun and as a bonus you don't really have 
to cook anything let the guests do the work right

alright let's get started many types of Asian hot 
pots don't require for the meat to be marinated at

all and in those cases the pieces are sliced super 
paper-thin but if you're going to hand slice if

you know just as thin as you can with a knife you 
want to give them meat a little extra flavor and

Thai people are always about extra flavor a little 
bit of oyster sauce in there I'm going to also add

a little soy sauce and put a little oil in there 
a little lubrication will help prevent the meat

from drying out when you dip it in the broth we're 
going to add some egg white I'm just going to use

my shell here as a spoon and spoon out just about 
a tablespoon of egg white and add that to my meat

and then save that egg because we will use that 
for the hotpot itself just the touch of tapioca

starch you can use corn starch instead and what's 
going to happen I've done this before by the way

in myitlab not episode and the egg white and the 
starch is going to form so the really invisibly

thin layer around the meat and when you dip it in 
the broth it'll seal the juices inside create a

little bit of a wrapping and the meat will be 
so juicy and tender for a hot pot you want to

have a few types of meat going so I've also got 
some chicken breasts here and I've done the same

thing using the same marinade and I also want to 
have some pork so this is pork jowl and I clearly

bought this from the store because for some reason 
the pre sliced version was cheaper than the whole

piece hmm interesting so pork jowl if you haven't 
tried it before is I think the best cut of the

pork look how much fat is buried in that piece 
and it's so tender so juicy so flavorful I'm not

gonna even marinate this because I know that pork 
jowl acid is just so delicious so if you can get

ahold of some pork jowl grate on the barbecue mmm 
so good all right so now we're gonna make the dim

part of dim dome which is the dipping sauce really 
simple really easy I've got some fish sauce here

mmm fish sauce lime juice of course and to give it 
a little body I am adding some tamarind juice now

you can do all lime if you want but I just find 
it has a little more complexity it's a touch of

sugar to make it not so sharp stir that until it's 
dissolved and now you want this spicy dim tail I

mean dim doom has to be spicy otherwise it's not 
the the spirit of dimdim so I've got here roasted

chili flakes dump that in there and roasted chili 
flakes is just dried chilies that I roasted in

the oven until it's smoky and just blitzed in a 
coffee grinder super easy to make I'm also going

to add some fresh herbs to it some green onions 
and some sawtooth coriander and now if you can't

find sawtooth coriander cilantro will work just 
fine or you can use mint if you like just going

to give them a quick chop chop chop one more 
ingredient to this dipping sauce I'm not going

to add till the last minute is toasted rice powder 
okay now if I add this now it will start to absorb

the liquid and swell up and that's not good so 
that's a last-minute thing check out my bounty of

vegetables you can use whatever kind of vegetables 
you want but keep in mind that the vegetables

will end up eventually flavoring the broth so I 
wouldn't go with certain things like asparagus

or broccoli that will have a strong flavor so 
these are actually what I've got is very classic

of course for hotpot the most important part is 
the broth so what I've got here is some plain

pork stock so that's just pork bones simmered in 
water for a couple of hours skim off all the scum

for this I didn't even use the aromatics that I 
normally do I'm going to flavor this broth with

what I call the thumb yum Trinity so the familiar 
herbs lemongrass galangal and kaffir lime leaves

and the galangal is frozen and that's how I store 
mine so all in the pool Oh almost forgot for the

live leaves I want to tear them before I drop 
them to help the flavor come out so you want

to be really rough with it just Bruce it now I 
want to bring this to a boil and I'm going to

flavor this broth a little bit because you know 
you're going to be sipping the broth you don't

want this completely bland just lightly seasoned 
with some fish sauce and I'm using this brand new

fish sauce that I just got it's like seven bucks 
really expensive so this is luxury fish sauce

here just a touch of fish sauce okay it should 
just be like a mildly salted broth so I'll let

that simmer for about three to five minutes to 
allow all the flavours to infuse so while that's

going a final touch on the meat remember that egg 
left over from the marinade I'm going to pop it

right in the middle of this meat platter here 
and by the way check out this meat platter is

not pretty so the egg is going to go right there 
and you'll see how we're going to use that egg

in the second the toasted rice powder is gonna 
go into the dipping sauce and if you don't know

how to make toasted rice powder I'll definitely 
put a link up here so you can check it out I'm

telling you that transforms it yes and the rest 
of the toasted rice powder is actually going to

go into the broth there we go and it's going to 
make the broth nice and toasty and you want that

to be the last thing before you eat because the 
rice will continue to absorb the broth so if you

do it ahead of time then the rice will just kind 
of swell up in there I mean that will eventually

happen as you eat but you don't want it to start 
out like that alright the first thing you want to

do is put in your veg doubles my boom some carrot 
ribbons mushrooms and of course at this point you

want to go in with a Thai basil and the Sawtooth 
coriander C and this is so much fun right so

you can get all your guests to do it together oh 
and you probably also would have some carbs I've

almost forgot to mention and the classic carp for 
this is glass noodles so glass noodles are made

of mung beans actually so I've soaked this in 
water for about seven to ten minutes until it's

pliable it'll take about a couple minutes to cook 
in the broth so you can add that in whenever you

want I'm going to start cooking the meat so I'm 
going to go in with this beef that we marinate

it and now I'm going to dip this in the egg yolk 
yeah there you go and the egg yolk I mean some

of it will wash off but some of it will sort of 
give the meat another coating which will prevent

it from drying out in the broth and now it gets a 
dunk this is a tomb of Tim tomb in this broth and

I'm not even letting it go I'm just gonna swish 
it around a couple times with my chopsticks here

there you go and now the Tim part I'm going to dip 
it into my numb team here oh my god it's so good

so tender now the vegetables and you want to leave 
the herbs behind so the kaffir lime leaves in the

lemongrass and all that just a little of the 
dipping sauce in my vegetables and it's just

sort of this is how the eating process goes you 
know you take a bite of meat a bite of vegetables

whenever you're ready you take noodles but as 
you can see I'm like having a party by myself

right here so it would be awesome if there were 
like five other people and everyone misstatements

doing all the time so I hope you give this a try 
the recipe as always will be on hot Thai Kitchen

calm when you make it send me a photo send me a 
photo of your hot spot party on facebook twitter

or instagram and please subscribe to the show 
if you haven't done so and I will see you next

time for your next delicious Thai meal makes 
the broth nice and toasty again whoa careful
